questions.question: A 5-year-old child presents with symptoms of mild to moderate dehydration. You are evaluating the clinical signs to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following combinations is true for some dehydration in this child? Decreased urine output Lethargy Delayed skin pinch Sunken eyeballs
questions.explanation: depletion in intravascular space. Additional symptoms may include irritability, restlessness, sunken eyes, no tear production, dry mucous membranes, and slightly delayed skin pinch test (<2 sec). Whereas, lethargy is not seen in some dehydration; rather, it is a feature of severe dehydration . Assessment and Classification of Dehydration in Children: Sign/Symptom No Dehydration Some Dehydration Severe Dehydration Mental status Alert Irritable/restless Lethargic/unconscious Loss of body weight <3% 3- 9% >9% Thirst Normal Increased Unable to drink Eyes Normal Slightly sunken Very sunken Tears Present Decreased Absent Mouth Moist Dry Parched Skin turgor Normal (Immediate recoil) Slow recoil (2-3sec) Very slow recoil (>3sec) Capillary refill Normal (<2sec) Prolonged (2-3sec) Prolonged (>3sec) Urine output Normal Decreased Minimal Treatment of Dehydration in Children: Rehydration: Plan A: For no dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool < 2 years: 50-100 ml of ORS administered. 2-10 years: 100-200 ml of ORS administered. >10 years: As much ORS as a child wants. Plan B: For some dehydration. The amount of ORS administered is 75ml/kg of body weight Plan C: For severe dehydration. Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as IV fluids. Age First 30 ml/kg in Next 70 ml/kg in Total 100 ml/kg in <12 months 1 hour 5 hours 6 hours >12 months 30 min 2.5 hours 3 hours Nutrition: Continue breastfeeding Reintroduce age-appropriate diet early Avoid fatty foods and simple sugars Zinc Supplementation: <6 months: 10 mg/day >6 months: 20 mg/day Medications: Antibiotics: Use judiciously, mainly for severe bacterial cases Ondansetron (for vomiting) Avoid antimotility agents Probiotics: It may be beneficial, especially for rotavirus ORS Composition (WHO standard): Constituent mmol/L Sodium 75 Glucose 75 Potassium 20 Chloride 65 Citrate 10 Total osmolarity 245 Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Pages 2027, 2028, 2029, 2030 Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th edition, Pages 287, 288, 289

DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is used in children as a maintenance fluid because: Prevents Hypoglycemia: Provides around 17 calories/ 100ml of 5%D as energy , crucial for children with higher metabolic rates. questions.question: A child was brought to the casualty with complaints of vomiting and loose stools with a history of laxative use. On examination, arrhythmia is present. What will be the abnormality present?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hypokalemia Explanation Vomiting and loose stools, along with cardiac arrhythmia, point to the diagnosis of hypokalemia . Normal serum potassium level: 3.5-5.5 meq/L. Hypokalemia is defined as a serum potassium level below 3.5 mEq/L. Mild hypokalemia: 3 - 3.5 mEq/L Moderate hypokalemia: 2.5 - 3.0 mEq/L Severe hypokalemia: <2.5 mEq/L Etiology: Common causes of hypokalemia in children include: Gastrointestinal losses (diarrhoea, vomiting) Renal losses (diuretics, renal tubular disorders) Inadequate intake Transcellular shifts (e.g., insulin administration, beta-agonists) Clinical features: Muscle weakness Fatigue Constipation Cardiac arrhythmias (in severe cases) Polyuria and polydipsia Treatment: The treatment of hypokalemia depends on its severity and the presence of symptoms. In this case, with moderate hypokalemia and symptoms, intravenous replacement is appropriate Potassium Supplementation: Indications for IV Potassium Supplementation: Symptomatic patients Severe hypokalemia (<2.5 mEq/L) Presence of ECG abnormalities Unable to tolerate oral feeds. IV Potassium Chloride Supplementation: Dosage: 0.5-1 mEq/kg per dose Administration: IV infusion over 1-2 hours Infusion Rate: Do not exceed 1 mEq/kg per hour Potassium Concentration: Maximum of 60 mEq/L for peripheral lines Maximum of 80 mEq/L for central lines Avoid using glucose-containing fluids to prevent insulin-mediated intracellular potassium shift. Oral Potassium Supplementation: Dosage: 2-4 mEq/kg per day, divided into 3-4 doses Common Preparations: Potassium chloride (10%; 20 mEq/15 mL) Potassium citrate (especially for renal tubular acidosis) Administration Tip: Liquid preparations can be bitter; dilute with juice or water to improve taste. Additional Management Considerations: Replace ongoing potassium losses Ensure volume resuscitation with normal saline Correct any associated hypomagnesemia Treat underlying conditions (e.g., monogenic hypertension, Bartter syndrome, Gitelman syndrome) Hyponatremia (Option A) can be caused due to GI losses but is not associated with cardiac arrhythmias. Hypocalcemia (Option B) is not associated with arrhythmias but rather presents with prolonged QT intervals and congestive cardiac failure. Hyperkalemia (Option D) is associated with cardiac arrhythmias but is not caused due to vomiting and diarrhoea. Reference: OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 63, 64

questions.question: A 10-year-old child is got to the OPD with complaints of poor appetite and failure to thrive. Upon further clinical examination, loss of skin turgor, and dry mucous membranes are noted. What is the glucose content of the rehydration solution used to treat this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 125 mmol/L Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate dehydration in a malnourished child requiring ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition). The patient presents with classic signs of dehydration including poor appetite, failure to thrive, loss of skin turgor, and dry mucous membranes . ReSoMal is specifically formulated for malnourished children with a precise glucose concentration of 125 mmol/L . This solution differs from standard oral rehydration solutions by having lower sodium and higher potassium content to address the specific needs of malnourished children. The osmolality of approximately 300 mOsm/L helps maintain appropriate fluid balance during rehydration. Composition of Rehydration Solutions Component Resomal (300 mOsm/L) Standard ORS (311 mOsm/L) Reduced Osmolarity ORS (245 mOsm/L) Sodium 45 mmol/L 90 mmol/L 75 mmol/L Potassium 40 mmol/L 20 mmol/L 20 mmol/L Chloride 70 mmol/L 80 mmol/L 65 mmol/L Citrate 7 mmol/L 10 mmol/L 10 mmol/L Glucose 125 mmol/L 111 mmol/L 75 mmol/L Zinc 40 µ mol/L - - Copper 70 µ mol/L - - Magnesium 3 mmol/L - - Total Osmolarity 300 mOsm/L 311 mOsm/L 245 mOsm/L 100 mmol/L (Option A) : This glucose concentration is too low for effective rehydration in malnourished children. A lower glucose concentration would not provide adequate carbohydrate substrate for sodium-glucose cotransport in the intestine. 150 mmol/L (Option C) : This concentration exceeds the recommended glucose content for ReSoMal. Higher glucose concentrations can lead to osmotic diarrhea and worsen dehydration. 200 mmol/L (Option D) : This concentration is significantly higher than the standard ReSoMal formulation. Such high glucose concentrations can cause osmotic fluid shifts and potentially worsen the child's condition. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 340-341. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5657219/

questions.question: Which of the following fluid solutions is preferred as the maintenance fluid for pediatric patients?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 0.9% Normal Saline in 5% Dextrose (N 5% D) Explanation: Current Best Practice : Isotonic fluids are now preferred for maintenance therapy in children, as recommended by: American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP, 2018) European Society of Pediatric and Neonatal Intensive Care (ESPNIC) WHO and national health bodies These guidelines were updated due to the risk of hospital-acquired hyponatraemia associated with hypotonic fluids. Reason for Isotonic Preference : Children have higher levels of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) during illness or stress → increased risk of water retention and dilutional hyponatraemia. 0.9% Normal Saline maintains plasma tonicity and reduces this risk. Role of Dextrose and Potassium : 5% Dextrose : Prevents hypoglycaemia and provides energy. Potassium (usually 20 mmol/L KCl) : Often added unless contraindicated, especially if the child is not eating or passing urine. 0.2% NS + 5% Dextrose (Option A) : Too hypotonic → high risk of hyponatraemia. 0.45% NS + 10% Dextrose (Option C) : Still hypotonic, and 10% Dextrose is excessive for routine use. 0.225% NS + 5% Dextrose (Option D) : Also hypotonic; once commonly used but now largely outdated. Reference: .https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560540/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11321816/

questions.question: An 18-month-old child with a 3-day history of watery diarrhea and vomiting presented with altered sensorium. Which of the following are differential diagnoses? Severe dehydration Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) Cerebral Venous Thrombosis Hyponatremia
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, 4 Explanation: In a child presenting with diarrhea, vomiting, and altered sensorium, the differential diagnosis should focus on conditions associated with metabolic derangements, dehydration, and potential neurological complications. Severe Dehydration (1): Prolonged diarrhea and vomiting can lead to hypovolemia and electrolyte imbalances, resulting in altered sensorium. This is one of the most common causes of altered mental status in children with diarrheal illness. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT) (3): Severe dehydration increases the risk of thrombosis due to hemoconcentration. CVT can present with seizures, altered sensorium, and focal neurological signs. Hyponatremia (4): Excessive water intake or inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (ADH) release in response to dehydration can cause dilutional hyponatremia. Symptoms include seizures, lethargy, and altered sensorium. Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) (2): This condition is typically associated with bloody diarrhea, which is absent in the clinical presentation. HUS is caused by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli and usually occurs several days after an initial diarrheal illness. Reference: O.P Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 10th Edition, Page: 487,488, 572.

questions.question: A 10-year-old child weighing 30 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? RBS 550 mg/dL pH 7.01 Na+ 158 mEq/L Urine glucose 3+

options.A: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
options.B: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
options.C: Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
options.D: Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour Explanation: 10-year-old , 30 kg child Severe dehydration Hyperglycaemia (RBS = 550 mg/dL) Acidosis (pH = 7.01) Hypernatremia (Na I = 158 mEq/L) Glucosuria This is a case of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) with severe dehydration , likely precipitated by diarrhoea. ISPAD Guidelines – Initial Management of DKA : ABC Stabilisation : Always assess and stabilise airway, breathing, and circulation first. Fluid Resuscitation : In severe dehydration or shock , give 0.9% Normal Saline (NS) 10–20 mL/kg over 1–2 hours . In this case (30 kg child with severe dehydration), give 20 mL/kg → 600 mL NS bolus . Insulin : Do not start insulin immediately . Begin insulin infusion after at least 1 hour of fluid resuscitation , to avoid rapid shifts in osmolality and risk of cerebral oedema. Dose: 0.05–0.1 IU/kg/hour , IV infusion. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): DKA is a frequent complication in children and adolescents with type 1 or type 2 diabetes mellitus. Clinical signs: Dehydration Tachycardia and tachypnea Kussmaul respiration : Deep sighing respiration with a ketotic breath odor (like nail polish remover or rotten fruit). Gastrointestinal symptoms : Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Neurological symptoms : Confusion, drowsiness, progressive loss of consciousness. Biochemical criteria for DKA diagnosis : Hyperglycemia : Blood glucose >11 mmol/L or ≥ 200 mg/dL. Acidosis: Venous: pH <7.3 and/or bicarbonate <15 mmol/L. Ketosis : Ketonemia: Blood β -hydroxybutyrate concentration ≥ 3 mmol/L. Ketonuria: Moderate or large ketones in urine. DKA Management in Children Immediate Management (First Hour): Rapid Assessment: Evaluate the child's vital signs (heart rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure) and weight. Assess GCS and check for signs of dehydration. Obtain blood samples for urgent measurement of blood glucose, blood beta-hydroxybutyrate (BHB) if available, venous pH, electrolytes (including bicarbonate), serum urea nitrogen, and creatinine. Serum BHB concentration : Most precise approach to measuring the severity of DKA Establish IV Access: Place two large-bore peripheral IV lines. Central lines are generally avoided (risk of thrombosis) unless necessary. Initial Fluid Resuscitation Administer a bolus of 0.9% saline at a rate of 10-20 ml/kg over 20-30 minutes to restore circulatory volume and address dehydration. After First Hour Initiate Insulin Therapy Start an intravenous insulin infusion at 0.05-0.1 U/kg/h , typically one hour after initiating fluids. Continue Fluid Therapy After the initial bolus, continue fluid replacement with 0.45% to 0.9% saline, to replace the estimated fluid deficit over 24 to 48 hours. Adjust fluids based on clinical status and laboratory values. Monitoring and Replacing Electrolytes Begin potassium replacement once urine output is confirmed as insulin causes K+ entry into cells, leading to hypokalemia. Monitor vital signs, GCS, fluid balance, and capillary blood glucose every hour. Reassess electrolytes, blood glucose, blood urea nitrogen, calcium, magnesium, phosphate, blood gases, and BOHB every two hours if available. questions.question: A 10-month-old child undergoes treatment for diarrhoea with hypokalemia but the child does not respond to the treatment appropriately and on examination muscular weakness is noted, what is the most likely cause of treatment failure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Hypomagnesemia In a child with diarrhoea with hypokalemia, presenting with muscular weakness and a failure to respond to treatment is suggestive of hypomagnesemia . Hypomagnesemia: Aetiology: Gastrointestinal losses ( diarrhoea , steatorrhea, vomiting, IBD, celiac disease, etc) Potassium-lowering agents (ex: patiromer) Renal losses: Genetic diseases causing renal magnesium loss (Gitelman syndrome, Barter syndrome, familial hypomagnesemia with hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis, etc) Drugs (amphotericin, cisplatin, diuretics, mannitol, glucose, etc) Other metabolic disorders Hypokalemia Hypercalcemia Diabetes Chronic kidney disease Other causes: Poor intake Hungry bone syndrome Pancreatitis Insulin Intrauterine growth restriction Infants of diabetic mothers Clinical features: Secondary hypocalcemia Associated hypocalcemia or severe hypomagnesemia causes: Tetany Chvostek sign Trousseau sign Seizures Persistent hypocalcemia due to hypomagnesemia causes rickets in rare cases Hypokalemia Ecg: Flat T waves Lengthening of ST segment Arrhythmias Treatment: Severe hypomagnesemia Parenteral magnesium Dose: 25-50 mg/kg Slow IV infusion (IM in neonates) Long term therapy Oral administration Magnesium gluconate Magnesium oxide Magnesium sulfate IM injections (minimize diarrhoea) Nighttime nasogastric infusion (minimise diarrhoea) Options B, C, and D are incorrect as these are not associated with hypokalemia in diarrhoea. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page: 404-406.

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy weighing 30 kg has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he's NPO?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B- 1700 mL Explanation: Based on the Holliday-Segar method, the daily maintenance fluid requirement for a 7-year-old boy who weighs 30 kg can be estimated as follows: Calculation of maintenance fluid: Body weight Maintenance fluid (mL/kg/day) <10 kg 100 mL/kg 10-20 kg 1000 + 50 for each kg in excess of 10kg >20 kg 1500 + 20 for each kg in excess of 20kg In case of 7 year old boy of 30 kg weight: For the first 10 kg of body weight : 100 mL/kg/day = 10 kg × 100 mL/kg/day = 1000 mL/day For the next 10 kg (from 11 to 20 kg): an additional 50 mL/kg/day = 10 kg × 50 mL/kg/day = 500 mL/day For the remaining 10 kg (from 21 to 30 kg): an additional 20 mL/kg/day = 10 kg × 20 mL/kg/day = 200 mL/day Adding the results from the above calculations: 1000 mL/day + 500 mL/day + 200 mL/day = 1700 mL/day Reference: Pediatric Fluid and Electrolyte Therapy - PMC OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 57.

questions.question: A 5 year old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retracted after a few seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment for the child? danger signs develop

options.A: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center
options.B: Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
options.C: Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask mother to come back if some
options.D: Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

questions.explanation: refer to a higher centre Correct Answer D- Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate severe dehydration. The patient presents with characteristic features including irritability, hasty drinking, sunken eyes, and delayed skin pinch test, which are classic signs of severe dehydration requiring immediate intervention. In cases of severe dehydration, the most appropriate treatment would be to start intravenous (IV) fluids, administer IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre. Assessment and Management of Dehydration: Degree of Dehydration Clinical Features Management Mild Slightly increased thirst Normal urine output Normal skin turgor Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with a solution containing electrolytes and glucose Encourage the child to drink small, frequent amounts of the ORT solution Continue regular feeding if the child is not vomiting or unable to tolerate oral intake Moderate Increased thirst Decreased urine output Decreased tears Dry mucous membranes Delayed capillary refill (>2 seconds) Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with a solution containing electrolytes and glucose Administer ORT in larger amounts and more frequently Monitor vital signs (heart rate, blood pressure), urine output, and mental status Consider antiemetic medication if vomiting is present If unable to tolerate oral intake or deteriorating clinical status, consider intravenous fluids Severe Markedly increased thirst Minimal or no urine output Sunken eyes, lethargy, irritability Cool extremities, mottled or pale skin Altered mental status, decreased consciousness Initiate intravenous fluids with a bolus of isotonic saline or lactated Ringer's solution Administer maintenance intravenous fluids and correct electrolyte imbalances as necessary Monitor vital signs closely, including heart rate, blood pressure, oxygen saturation Address underlying causes, such as infections or other medical conditions Consider transfer to a higher level of care if there are signs of severe or life-threatening dehydration Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher centre (Option A): While antibiotic therapy may be indicated in some cases of diarrhea, the priority in this scenario is to address the dehydration and provide appropriate fluid replacement. Referral to a higher center is necessary for the management of severe dehydration. Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day (Option B): Given the signs of dehydration mentioned, providing oral fluids alone may not be adequate to correct the dehydration rapidly. Prompt intervention with IV fluids is required in severe dehydration cases. Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask the mother to come back if some danger signs develop (Option C): Zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution are essential components of managing diarrheal illnesses, but in cases of severe dehydration, intravenous fluid therapy is necessary.

questions.question: A 2-year-old boy is presented by his parents at a nearby village hospital, reporting loose stools over the past 3 days. The child's mother observes that he has become lethargic and refuses to eat. Upon examination, the child displays lethargy, dry mouth, sunken eyes, and delayed skin pinch recovery. How much fluid should be administered within the initial three hours if the child weighs 10 kg?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1000 ml Explanation: The patient's presentation with lethargy, dry mouth, sunken eyes, and delayed skin pinch recovery is suggestive of severe dehydration. In a severely dehydrated child, the initial fluid volume (intravenous) to be given is 100 ml/kg. Since the child's weight is 10 kg, the total fluid volume is 10kg x 100ml/kg =1000 ml. Dehydration - Treatment No dehydration: Continue normal diet Zinc: Reduces duration and severity of diarrhea in children from developing countries: Dose: 2-6-month age: 10 mg/day ≥ 6-month age: 20 mg/day Duration: 10-14 days Replacement of ongoing losses by WHO-ORS (5-10 ml/kg/loose stool) Some dehydration: 75 ml/kg over 4 hours (if cannot accept orally, give IV fluid) Severe dehydration: 100 ml/kg fluid IV Fluid Administration for Severe Dehydration: Age 1st 30ml/kg Next 70 ml/kg Total < 1 year Over 1 hour Over 5 hour 6 hours > 1 year Over ½ hour Over 2 ½ hours 3 hours IV fluid of choice: Ringer lactate in 5% Dextrose > Ringer lactate Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Pages 309-315

questions.question: At what age is surgery typically performed for cleft lip?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 3 months Explanation: Surgery for cleft lip is typically performed at around 3 months of age following the "Rule of 10s" , which provides safe criteria for timing of the operation: 10 weeks of age 10 pounds (approx. 4.5 kg) body weight 10 g/dL haemoglobin This early repair helps with feeding , speech development , and aesthetic outcomes . 6 months (Option B) : Is later than the usual timing for cleft lip repair. By this time, cleft palate repair may be planned. 1 year (Option C) : Typical age for cleft palate surgery, not lip. 18 months (Option D) : Too late for primary cleft lip repair; may be considered for revision surgeries or speech surgeries if required. questions.question: What is the diagnosis of the patient having the following type of karyotype, as shown in the image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Down Syndrome Explanation: The karyotype is showing three copies of chromosome 21 , which indicates it is a case of Down syndrome. Down Syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21, resulting in a total of 47 chromosomes instead of the normal 46. Key features of Karyotyping: A karyotype is a visual representation of an individual's chromosomes, arranged in pairs by size and position of the centromere. In a normal human karyotype, 46 chromosomes are arranged in 23 pairs (22 pairs of autosomes and 1 pair of sex chromosomes). The chromosomes are photographed during metaphase, when they are most condensed and visible. They are then arranged in descending order of size, with the sex chromosomes placed last. Turner Syndrome (Option A) is characterized by monosomy X, which means there is an absence or partial deletion of one of the X chromosomes, resulting in a karyotype of 45, XO. The presented karyotype shows three copies of chromosome 21, not a missing X chromosome. Turner syndrome affects only females and is associated with short stature and ovarian dysfunction. Klinefelter Syndrome (Option C) presents with an extra X chromosome in males , resulting in a karyotype of 47, XXY. The karyotype image clearly shows trisomy 21, not an extra X chromosome. Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by tall stature, infertility, and delayed puberty. Edward Syndrome (Option D) also known as Trisomy 18, is caused by an extra copy of chromosome 18, resulting in a karyotype of 47, XX+18 or 47, XY+18. The provided karyotype shows an extra chromosome 21, not chromosome 18. Edward syndrome is associated with severe developmental delays and multiple congenital anomalies. Reference: OP Ghai Essential Paediatrics 10th Edition, Page 666-668

questions.question: What is the diagnosis of a 10-year-old boy who was brought for psychiatric evaluation due to intellectual disability and exhibits an IQ of 45? The boy also presents with physical characteristics such as a long face, large ears, and large testes, along with a cardiac murmur. Additionally, there is a history of poor intellectual function in the paternal family.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Fragile X syndrome Explanation: The patient presents with the classic triad of physical features , including a long face, large ears, and macroorchidism (large testes), along with intellectual disability (IQ 45) and a cardiac murmur suggestive of mitral valve prolapse , which indicates Fragile X syndrome. The X-linked inheritance pattern is supported by the paternal family history of poor intellectual function. This condition is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome , making it the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability. Fragile X Syndrome: Genetic Basis CGG repeats on FMR-1 (Familial mental retardation) gene on X chromosome CGG Repeat Numbers Normal population: 5-55 repeats Carriers (premutation): 55-200 repeats Fragile X Syndrome: >200 repeats Gender Prevalence More common in males (X-Linked Dominant Inheritance) Females mostly carriers Clinical Features Long face & large ears Large mandible/Prominent jaw High arched palate Hyperextensible joints Mitral valve prolapse Macroorchidism/large testes (seen in adolescent age group) Intellectual disability Clinical features of female carriers May be associated with premature ovarian failure 10% may have an intellectual disability/low IQ Incorrect options: Cushing's syndrome (Option A): While this condition can affect growth and development, it typically presents with central obesity, moon face, and buffalo hump. The characteristic features of large ears and macroorchidism are not associated with Cushing's syndrome. Rett syndrome (Option B): This condition primarily affects females and is characterized by progressive loss of motor functions such as inability to speak, use hands, walk or perform other activities. It does not present with distinctive facial features or macroorchidism. William syndrome (Option D): While this condition can cause intellectual disability and cardiac abnormalities, it typically presents with elfin facies and a distinctive "cocktail party" personality. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459243/

questions.question: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Liver iron concentration Explanation: Liver iron concentration is the best method to detect iron overload in thalassemia patients undergoing multiple blood transfusions. Iron Overload in Thalassemia: Iron Overload Mechanisms in Thalassemia: TDT (Transfusion-Dependent Thalassemia): Regular blood transfusions lead to iron accumulation (0.3-0.6 mg/kg per day). Iron is released into plasma after transfused red blood cells are phagocytized and binds to transferrin. Once transferrin is saturated, non-transferrin-bound iron enters organs like the liver , heart, and endocrine glands. Iron accumulation causes organ damage via reactive oxygen species. NTDT (Non-Transfusion-Dependent Thalassemia): Increased intestinal iron absorption due to hepcidin suppression and ineffective erythropoiesis. Iron primarily accumulates in the liver , not the myocardium, unlike in TDT. Diagnosis and Quantification of Iron Overload: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): MRI with R2 or T2 technique is the gold standard for quantifying liver iron concentration (LIC) and cardiac iron in thalassemia. Iron Overload Thresholds: LIC in NTDT: Values >5 mg/g correlate with increased morbidity. LIC in TDT: 7 mg/g dw indicates increased risk of complications. 15 mg/g dw is predictive of advanced liver fibrosis and increased cardiac risk. Cardiac T2 MRI: (Option B) <10 ms predicts higher risk of heart failure and mortality. 10-20 ms is linked to reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and arrhythmias. However there can be discrepancy between liver iron and cardiac iron levels. Serum Ferritin Assessment: (Option C) Used as a screening tool. Ferritin levels correlate with hepatic iron overload in both TDT and NTDT. However, it is not as accurate for detecting iron overload in thalassemia patients, as ferritin levels can be elevated due to other factors (e.g., inflammation). Non-Transferrin-Bound Iron (NTBI): (Option D) Refers to iron that is not bound to transferrin, typically occurring in iron overload conditions when iron exceeds the binding capacity of transferrin. NTBI is a labile form of iron that can contribute to iron toxicity. While NTBI can serve as an indicator of iron overload, it is influenced by plasma factors like citrate, uric acid, and albumin. Management of Iron Overload in Thalassemia: Iron Chelation Therapy (ICT): Aims to manage iron stores, reduce iron in tissues, and reverse heart failure. Three main chelators used: Deferoxamine (DFO), Deferiprone (DFP), and Deferasirox (DFX). TDT: Start ICT after 10 transfusions or by age 2 years. NTDT: Begin assessment at age 10, with consideration for MRI-based evaluation of organ-specific iron load from age 8-10 years. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6142532/

Beta thalassemia: Results from mutations in the HBB gene on chromosome 11, which encodes the beta globin chains. questions.question: What is the inheritance pattern observed in neural tube defects?
questions.explanation: development. Examples of NTDs include spina bifida, anencephaly, and encephalocele. The pattern of Inheritance in NTDs is complex and can involve multiple genetic and environmental factors. While no single gene has been identified as causing NTDs, there is evidence to suggest that multiple genes may be involved. In addition to genetic factors, environmental factors such as maternal folic acid deficiency, certain medications, and exposure to toxins can also increase the risk of NTDs. Therefore, the inheritance pattern in NTDs is considered to be multifactorial, meaning that genetic and environmental factors contribute to the development of the condition. Incorrect Choices: a. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant inheritance occurs when a single copy of a mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disease. This is not the pattern of inheritance in NTDs b. X-linked dominant: X-linked dominant inheritance occurs when a mutated gene on the X chromosome is responsible for the disease. This is not the pattern of inheritance in NTDs c. Autosomal recessive: Autosomal recessive inheritance occurs when an individual inherits two copies of a mutated gene, one from each parent. This is not the pattern of inheritance in NTDs.

questions.question: Which of the following is not associated with Down's syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Caudal regression Explanation: Among the provided options, caudal regression is not associated with Down syndrome . Caudal regression is a condition characterized by the abnormal development of the lower spine and limbs, and it is more frequently seen in infants of diabetic mothers rather than those with Down syndrome. Down's Syndrome (Trisomy 21) Cause Trisomy 21 due to meiotic nondisjunction. Less commonly caused by Robertsonian translocation (4%) or mosaicism (1%). Incidence 1:800 to 1:1000 live births. General Features Craniofacial: Intellectual disability, flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes, epicanthic folds. Small nose, flat nasal bridge, narrow palate, small teeth, protruding tongue. Brachycephaly, flat occiput, dysplastic ears. Extremities: Short, broad hands, clinodactyly (5th finger), simian crease, sandal gap (wide space between toes). Comorbidities Cardiac: 40-60% have congenital heart defects (mainly AVSD, VSD, PDA, ASD). Gastrointestinal: Duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung disease, annular pancreas. Hematological: Increased risk of leukemia (acute lymphoblastic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia). Endocrine: Thyroid dysfunction (hypothyroidism), type 1 diabetes risk. Neurological: Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease (APP gene on chromosome 21). Musculoskeletal: Atlanto-occipital subluxation, short stature, hypotonia, growth delays, obesity risk. Sensory: Hearing loss (conductive, often due to serous otitis media), ophthalmic problems (cataracts, strabismus, nystagmus). Diagnosis Prenatal: Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS): Performed between 10-13 weeks. Amniocentesis: Performed after 15 weeks. Postnatal: Characteristic features (e.g., craniofacial dysmorphisms). Confirmatory Test: Karyotype analysis for trisomy 21. Antenatal Screening First Trimester: Increased nuchal translucency (>3 mm), elevated β -HCG, low PAPP-A. Second Trimester: Triple Test ( β -HCG, estriol, AFP), Quadruple Test (adds Inhibin-A). Integrated Test: Combines maternal age, NT, PAPP-A, and Quadruple Test. Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPS/NIPT): Cell-free fetal DNA testing (high sensitivity and specificity). Reference: Nelson Textbook of Paediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 659, 660. https://healthed.govt.nz/products/antenatal-screening-and-testing-for-down-syndrome-and-other-conditions https://www.ucsfhealth.org/education/prenatal-testing-for-down-syndrome

questions.question: Which of the following is a new drug approved by the FDA for the treatment of Rett syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Trofinetide Explanation: Trofinetide is the newly FDA-approved drug for the treatment of Rett syndrome, a rare neurodevelopmental disorder primarily affecting females. Trofinetide is a synthetic analog of the amino-terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1), designed to reduce neuroinflammation and support synaptic function. It is believed to work by inhibiting inflammatory cytokine production, reducing overactivation of microglia and astrocytes, and enhancing IGF-1 signaling in the brain, which is crucial for normal development and response to injury. Rett Syndrome Neurological disorder mostly affecting girls. Caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene . Characterized by normal early development, followed by loss of motor skills, speech, and purposeful hand movements. Development and Symptoms Early Development: Normal for the first 6-18 months. Loss of Skills: After early development, motor skills, speech, and purposeful hand movements are lost. Repetitive Hand Movements: Common signs include hand-wringing, clapping, or tapping. Motor Dysfunction: Loss of coordination, walking problems, and abnormal gait. Cognitive Impairment: Intellectual disability and delayed language development. Seizures: Commonly occur in many cases. Diagnosis: Genetic Testing to detect mutations in the MECP2 gene. Management: Symptom Management Antiepileptic drugs (e.g., valproic acid, lamotrigine) for seizures. SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors) Torfenetide: An investigational drug targeting MECP2 gene abnormalities to potentially enhance neurological function. Motor Support Speech Therapy Behavioral Therapy Olcegepant (Option A): A calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist that was considered for migraine treatment but was discontinued. Lasmiditan (Option B): A 5HT1F receptor-selective agonist used for treating migraine. Erenumab (Option D): A CGRP-blocking antibody used for treating migraines. Reference: Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics,14th Edition, Page: 292,293. Nelson Textbook of Paediatrics, 21st Edition, Page: 3192-3194. NCBI Books - National Library of Medicine Medscape - Daybue (Trofinetide)

Incorrect Options: Trisomy 13 (Option B): Incorrect, as Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) would show 47, XY, +13, not +18. Trisomy 21 (Option C): Incorrect, as Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is characterized by 47, XY, +21, not +18. Trisomy 11 (Option D): Not a recognized viable trisomy in humans. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 653-659

questions.question: A child was diagnosed with Turner syndrome. Which of the following are features of Turner syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Webbed neck Explanation: The image shows a webbed neck , which is a characteristic feature of Turner syndrome . Turner syndrome (45, XO) is a chromosomal disorder characterized by the absence of one X chromosome in females. Turner syndrome has multiple clinical manifestations that can be categorized using the SABLCOWN mnemonic: Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome (Mnemonic- SABCLOWN) S Short stature Short 4th metacarpal Sensorineural hearing loss A Amenorrhea (Primary) B Barr body absent C Cardiac abnormalities Cystic hygroma Cubitus valgus L Low posterior hairline Lymphedema of hands and feet Low thyroid (Hypothyroidism) O Ovaries streak-shaped/underdeveloped Rudimentary uterus W Webbed neck N Nipples are widely spaced on a shield-shaped chest Normal intelligence Normal height (Option B): Short stature is a cardinal feature of Turner syndrome. Growth failure typically becomes evident by age 3-5 years, and final adult height is significantly reduced without growth hormone therapy. Decreased carrying angle (Option C): Turner syndrome is characterized by an increased carrying angle (cubitus valgus), not a decreased angle. This increased carrying angle is one of the characteristic skeletal manifestations of the condition. Gynecomastia (Option D): Gynecomastia is not a feature of Turner syndrome. Gynecomastia is associated with Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY). Turner syndrome typically presents with widely spaced nipples on a shield-shaped chest. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 659

questions.question: A child with fused carpal bones comes to your clinic. What is the gene associated with hand-feet syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) HOXA13 Explanation: Hand-Foot-Genital Syndrome (HFGS): Rare, dominantly inherited condition affecting distal limbs and genitourinary tract. Genetic cause: Identified mutation in the HOXA13 homeobox gene. HFGS is the second human syndrome linked to a HOX gene mutation. Clinical Characteristics: Limb Malformations: Bilateral shortening of thumbs and great toes, typically involving distal phalanx or first metacarpal/metatarsal. Impaired dexterity or thumb apposition due to the malformations. Urogenital Defects: In females: Abnormalities in the ureters and urethra, incomplete müllerian fusion. In males: Hypospadias with or without chordee. Associated conditions: Vesicoureteral reflux, recurrent urinary tract infections, and chronic pyelonephritis. Normal fertility. Diagnosis and Testing: Clinical Diagnosis: Physical examination, radiographs of hands/feet, and imaging of kidneys, bladder, and female reproductive tract. Genetic Diagnosis: Identification of a heterozygous HOXA13 pathogenic variant confirms diagnosis if clinical/radiographic features are unclear. Management: Treatment of Manifestations: Surgery for hand/foot malformations is usually unnecessary. Ureteric reimplantation and bladder outlet abnormality correction often needed. Rare surgical correction for vaginal septum or uterine abnormalities, unless recurrent pregnancy loss occurs. Prevention of Secondary Complications: Prophylactic antibiotics or surgery for urinary tract issues. Gynecological exams before menstruation for hymenal constriction. Pre-pregnancy evaluation for uterine and vaginal anatomy due to risks in pregnancy. BCL6 gene (Option B) mutations are associated with B cell lymphomas and other cancers. FGFR gene (Option C) mutation causes skeletal disorders, mainly dwarfism and craniofacial malformations. COI 11 (Option D) mutation is associated with hearing loss. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10839976/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6965970/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4573649/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4075446

questions.question: What type of genetic inheritance is indicated by the pedigree chart?
questions.explanation: individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene, one from each parent, in order to express the disorder. Carriers (heterozygous individuals) do not show symptoms but can pass on the mutated gene to their offspring. The disorder can skip generations and is typically seen in individuals who have two affected parents or when both parents are carriers. Examples of autosomal-recessive disorders include cystic fibrosis and sickle cell anemia. Incorrect Options: Option A: Autosomal-dominant disorder: In an autosomal-dominant disorder, the affected individual has a 50% chance of passing on the mutated gene to each offspring. The disorder typically appears in every generation, and both males and females can be affected. Unaffected individuals do not transmit the disorder to their offspring. Examples of autosomal-dominant disorders include Huntington's disease and Marfan syndrome. Option B: X-linked dominant disorder: In an X-linked dominant disorder, an affected male passes the mutated gene to all of his daughters but none of his sons. Affected females have a 50% chance of passing on the mutated gene to each offspring, regardless of gender. The disorder can appear in every generation, but it is more commonly observed in females. Examples of X-linked dominant disorders include Rett syndrome and Incontinentia Pigmenti. Option D: X-linked recessive disorder: In an X-linked recessive disorder, affected males pass the mutated gene to all of their daughters but none of their sons. Carrier females have a 50% chance of passing on the mutated gene to each offspring. The disorder is more commonly observed in males. Examples of X-linked recessive disorders include hemophilia and Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Reference: .

questions.question: An infant presents with vomiting after feeding. A Benedict’s test was performed and returned positive for a non-glucose substance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Galactosemia due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase enzyme deficiency
options.B: Hereditary fructose intolerance due to aldolase B deficiency
options.D: Galactosemia due to galactokinase enzyme deficiency

questions.explanation: most likely diagnosis, given the presentation of vomiting after feeding and a positive Benedict’s test for a non-glucose substance, consistent with the presence of galactose in the urine. Incorrect Options: Option B - Hereditary fructose intolerance due to aldolase B deficiency: Hereditary fructose intolerance results from a deficiency in aldolase B, leading to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate after ingestion of fructose, sucrose, or sorbitol. Symptoms include vomiting, hypoglycemia, and liver damage. The Benedict’s test would show a positive result for fructose, but this condition typically presents after the introduction of fructose-containing foods, not in the newborn period. Option C - Glucose-6-Phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency: G6PD deficiency leads to hemolytic anemia, particularly after exposure to certain triggers like infections or certain foods/drugs. This condition does not typically cause a positive Benedict’s test for a non-glucose substance, nor does it present with vomiting after feeding. Option D - Galactosemia due to galactokinase enzyme deficiency: This milder form of galactosemia results from a deficiency in galactokinase, leading to the accumulation of galactose, which can cause cataracts. However, it usually does not cause severe systemic symptoms like those seen in GAL-1-P uridyl transferase deficiency, and the Benedict’s test would still be positive for galactose.

questions.question: A floppy infant presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and an X-ray showing cardiomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pompe disease Explanation: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder (Type II) caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase (acid maltase). It leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes, primarily affecting cardiac and skeletal muscle. Clinical features include: Floppy infant with profound hypotonia ("floppy baby") Cardiomegaly due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy Hepatomegaly from glycogen accumulation Respiratory distress and feeding difficulties The combination of hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly on X-ray fits classic infantile Pompe disease. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) (Option B): TGA is a cyanotic congenital heart defect with discordant ventriculoarterial connections. Presents with cyanosis, not hypotonia or hepatomegaly. Cardiomegaly may be present, but hepatomegaly and hypotonia are not typical. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) (Option C): TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with right ventricular outflow obstruction, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and RV hypertrophy. Presents with cyanosis and "tet spells." Hypotonia and hepatomegaly are not usual features. Ebstein's anomaly (Option D): A congenital malformation of the tricuspid valve causing atrialization of the right ventricle. Presents with cyanosis, heart failure signs, but does not typically cause hypotonia or hepatomegaly in infancy. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1261/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2721312/

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with pain, redness, and swelling around his great toe. His serum uric acid level is 9.4 mg/dL. His mother also mentions that he frequently bites his lips and has symptoms of spasticity and dystonia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase Explanation: The clinical manifestations, such as combination of hyperuricemia (leading to gout-like symptoms), neurological manifestations including dystonia and spasticity, and self-mutilating behavior such as lip-biting indicate Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, an X-linked recessive disorder , is caused by a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which results in impaired purine metabolism. Pathophysiology: HGPRT deficiency leads to: Accumulation of purine metabolites Excessive uric acid production Neurological complications (dystonia and spasticity) Lesch-Nyhan syndrome Cause Deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) Inheritance X-linked recessive Variants Classic Lesch-Nyhan syndrome : Undetectable HPRT levels. Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome : Partial HPRT deficiency with variable neurological dysfunction. Clinical Features Self-injurious behaviour : Biting lips, fingers, tongue; begins with tooth eruption. Cognitive impairment : Intellectual disability ranging from mild to severe. Movement disorder : Starts with hypotonia, progresses to dystonia, choreoathetosis, oromandibular dystonia, and inspiratory stridor. Oculomotor apraxia : Difficulty controlling eye movements. Dysarthric speech : Difficulty speaking clearly. Complications Hyperuricemia : Causes gout and kidney stones. Neurological symptoms : Abnormalities in the dopamine system, reduced dopamine transporters. Treatment Allopurinol : Reduces uric acid levels and manages hyperuricemia. Symptom management : Controls movement disorders and self-injurious behaviours. Incorrect Options: Cystathionine beta-synthase (Option A): This enzyme is involved in homocysteine metabolism, and its deficiency would lead to homocystinuria with manifestations like lens dislocation, skeletal abnormalities, and thromboembolism . It does not cause hyperuricemia or self-mutilating behavior. Dihydrothymidine oxidase (Option B): This enzyme is involved in pyrimidine metabolism, and its deficiency would not cause elevated uric acid levels or neurological symptoms seen in this case. Xanthine oxidase (Option D): Deficiency of this enzyme causes xanthinuria, characterized by low uric acid levels, not elevation as seen in this case. Its manifestations include abdominal pain, recurrent UTI, hematuria & muscle cramping. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 3158

questions.question: A 3-year-old child immediately cries after breastfeeding, followed by vomiting and diarrhea. Which enzyme deficiency might be responsible?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyl Transferase Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate Galactosemia , a disorder caused by Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency . The immediate symptoms after breast milk ingestion, including crying, vomiting, and diarrhea, are hallmark features of this condition. Galactosemia Enzyme Deficiency Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT) - Classical type Galactokinase - benign disease with only oil drop cataract. Epimerase - SNHL + symptoms of classical type (Low galactose-based diet can be given, which is contraindicated in the classical type) Pathophysiology Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate (toxic causing jaundice, and liver damage) Inability to metabolize galactose from milk Damage to liver, kidney, and brain Clinical Features Hepatic: Jaundice, hepatomegaly GI: Vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive CNS: Seizures, intellectual disability Eyes: Oil drop cataracts Increased risk of E. coli sepsis Diagnosis Reducing substance in urine (positive) (Positive Benedict test but negative glucose oxidase test) Direct enzyme (GALT) assay Genetic testing (Perinatal diagnosis is possible) Management Lactose-free diet Breast Milk contraindicated Soy-based or elemental formulas Calcium supplementation Incorrect Options: Aldolase B (Option A): This enzyme deficiency results in hereditary fructose intolerance, causing symptoms after fructose ingestion rather than milk consumption. The presenting symptoms would be triggered by fruits and sweet foods, not breast milk. Phenylalanine Hydroxylase (Option B): Deficiency of this enzyme causes phenylketonuria (PKU), presenting with developmental delay and neurological symptoms rather than acute post-feeding distress. PKU symptoms are not immediately related to breast milk ingestion. Glucocerebrosidase (Option D): This enzyme deficiency leads to Gaucher disease, characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, bone problems, and hematological abnormalities. It does not cause acute gastrointestinal symptoms after milk ingestion. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Pages 788 and 789

questions.question: Which vitamin deficiency can result in seizures in newborns?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pyridoxine Explanation: Deficiency of pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) can lead to refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is essential for the proper functioning of the nervous system, and its deficiency can disrupt normal brain development and function, leading to seizures in newborns. Deficiency of thiamine (Vitamin B1) (Option B) can result in a condition called beriberi, which primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems but does not typically cause neonatal seizures. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) (Option C) is necessary for energy production and the metabolism of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins. While riboflavin deficiency can lead to various symptoms, including skin and eye abnormalities, it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures. Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) (Option D) is involved in the synthesis of coenzyme A, which is essential for energy metabolism. Deficiency of pantothenic acid is not associated with neonatal seizures. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): RDA: 0.1-0.3 mg/day Dietary Sources: Banana, wheat germ, rice, sunflower seeds, fish, poultry. Pyridoxine (B6) deficiency Cause High protein intake. Certain medications (eg. Isoniazid) Oral contraceptives. Dialysis. Clinical features: Infants: Irritability, seizures , vomiting, failure to thrive. Adults: Peripheral neuritis, cheilosis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis, anemia. Dependency Syndromes: Pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy, Vitamin B6-responsive anemia. Diagnosis: Low AST/ALT, high urinary xanthurenic acid, EEG response to pyridoxine. Treatment: Convulsions: 100 mg pyridoxine IM/IV, then oral intake. Dependency: 2-10 mg IM or 10-100 mg orally daily. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page 735, 736, 3099

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 10-year-old child who is brought to the clinic with developmental delay and extrapyramidal symptoms and is found to have a lens dislocation towards the inferonasal area during further examination?

While it can also present with ectopia lentis, it is not associated with the developmental delays and extrapyramidal symptoms. questions.question: A 2-week-old infant presents with a history of epistaxis and recurrent rectal bleeding. The parents also reported a history of bleeding from the umbilicus since birth. Laboratory investigations revealed normal prothrombin time (PT), normal thrombin time, normal activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), normal platelet count, and normal function. Urea clot solubility test was positive. What is the most likely deficient factor in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Factor XIII Explanation: The given clinical feature is characteristic of Factor XIII (FXIII) deficiency / Laki lorand factor deficiency. It is a rare bleeding disorder that presents with symptoms spanning from delayed umbilical cord separation to intracranial hemorrhage. FXIII plays a pivotal role in stabilizing clots and facilitating the cross-linking of the fibrin polymer, thereby ensuring effective hemostasis The acquired FXIII deficiency typically arises from factors such as hyperconsumption, hemodilution, and decreased synthesis and is more prevalent than the congenital form. In rare instances, individuals with acquired FXIII deficiency may generate autoantibodies targeting FXIII subunits. Factor XI deficiency (Option B) and Factor XII deficiency (Option D) causes prolonged Activated partial prothrombin time (aPTT) but Prothrombin time (PT) will be normal. Factor X deficiency (Option C) causes both prolonged Prothrombin time (PT) and Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557467/ Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis Of Disease, 10th edition, Page 668, 669

questions.question: A child presented with anemia, mental retardation, bone pains, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance. What is the enzyme deficiency producing this condition?
questions.explanation: pains, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance. The enzyme deficiency producing this condition is Glucocerebrosidase , which is associated with Gaucher disease. Incorrect Options: Option A - Hexosaminidase-A : This enzyme deficiency is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, which is characterized by progressive neurological degeneration, but it does not typically present with the "crumpled tissue paper" appearance in bone marrow or the specific combination of symptoms described (anemia, mental retardation, bone pains, hepatosplenomegaly). Option B - Iduronate 2-sulphatase : Deficiency of this enzyme is associated with Hunter syndrome, a type of mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS II). This condition can cause developmental delay, skeletal abnormalities, and hepatosplenomegaly but does not typically present with the "crumpled tissue paper" appearance in bone marrow. Option C - Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase : Deficiency in this enzyme leads to G6PD deficiency, which can cause hemolytic anemia but does not typically cause the "crumpled tissue paper" appearance in bone marrow or the combination of symptoms described.

questions.question: An 18-month-old child presents with hepatosplenomegaly, a hemoglobin level of 7 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 50,000 cells/cu.mm, and petechiae and purpura. What is the recommended drug treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation: treatment regimen for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Vincristine is a chemotherapy agent that inhibits cell division, and Prednisolone is a corticosteroid that helps reduce inflammation and has antitumor effects. This option is appropriate if the child's symptoms are indicative of ALL, as the high WBC count and symptoms like hepatosplenomegaly and purpura are consistent with leukemia. Incorrect Options: Option B – IVIG: Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is used for treating immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) and other conditions involving immune-mediated platelet destruction. While IVIG can be beneficial in conditions with bleeding tendencies, it is not typically used as the primary treatment for leukemia. Option C - L-Asparaginase + Prednisolone: L-Asparaginase is an enzyme used in the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) as part of a chemotherapy regimen. It works by depleting asparagine, an amino acid necessary for leukemia cell survival. Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used to enhance the effects of chemotherapy and reduce inflammation. This combination is appropriate for treating ALL, but without additional context, it’s less specific than Vincristine + Prednisolone in a classic ALL regimen. Option D - Daunorubicin + Prednisolone: Daunorubicin is a chemotherapy drug used primarily in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and sometimes in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used to support chemotherapy treatment. This combination is generally used for AML rather than ALL.

questions.question: Which of the following is least likely regarding Rh incompatibility in a newborn?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Increased urine bilirubin Explanation: In Rh incompatibility, maternal antibodies destroy fetal Rh-positive RBCs , leading to hemolysis and excessive unconjugated bilirubin (Option A). Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and bound to albumin, preventing urinary excretion. Instead, intestinal bacteria convert it to urobilinogen and stercobilinogen, which are eliminated in stool. (Options B & D) Urine bilirubin consists of conjugated bilirubin, which requires hepatic processing. However, in Rh incompatibility, the liver is overwhelmed, leading to predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and no significant increase in urine bilirubin . Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page 953, 956

questions.question: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9 th month. Which of the following investigations is used for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Globin gene sequencing Explanation: In this case, the presence of target cells and a history of repeated blood transfusions suggests a possible hemoglobinopathy, such as thalassemia or sickle cell disease . Globin gene sequencing is a molecular diagnostic test that can identify specific mutations or genetic alterations in the globin genes. By sequencing the globin genes, such as the alpha and beta globin genes, it is possible to identify the specific genetic abnormality responsible for the hemoglobinopathy. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Option A) is a commonly used method to measure the different types of hemoglobin and their variants in the blood. While HPLC can help in identifying abnormal hemoglobin variants, it may not provide a definitive diagnosis of the underlying genetic abnormality causing the hemoglobinopathy. Estimating ferritin levels (Option B) can provide information about the iron stores in the body but may not directly help in diagnosing the underlying cause of the anemia or the specific genetic abnormality causing the hemoglobinopathy. While bone marrow examination (Option C) can provide valuable information about the cells in the bone marrow, it may not always be necessary for the definitive diagnosis of hemoglobinopathy Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th edition, Page 363

questions.question: A patient has bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis, which has very little interference with his daily activities. Based on further workup, a diagnosis of a mild case of ITP is made. How will you manage the patient?

options.C: A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Education, counseling, and watchful expectancy Explanation: In a patient with mild ITP who has bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis but minimal interference with daily activities , the preferred approach is watchful expectancy. Most cases of mild ITP in children resolve spontaneously without treatment. Regular follow-up visits can help assess the progression of the disease and determine the need for intervention if symptoms worsen or if there is an increase in bleeding risk. The observation period involves providing education and counseling to the patient and closely monitoring platelet counts and symptoms over time. Management of Immune thrombocytopenic purpura in children Based on platelet count: Platelet Count >30,000 cells/ µ L + No severe bleeding- Monitor closely Platelet Count < 30,000 cells/ µ L + No severe bleeding + Platelet Count ≥ 5,000 cells/ µ L: Glucocorticoids (e.g., Prednisone , Dexamethasone) Platelet Count < 5,000 cells/ µ L or Severe Bleeding: i.v.i.g.+ Glucocorticoids Other modalities: Immediate Need to Raise Platelet Count like surgery or trauma- Platelet Transfusion Persistent or Severe Cases- Monitor with intermittent i.v.i.g. If necessary, consider Splenectomy Alternative Medications: Anti-CD20 Antibody: Rituximab TPO Receptor Agonists: Romiplostim, Eltrombopag Short course corticosteroid therapy (Option A) is not indicated as the first-line treatment for mild ITP with minimal symptoms. While corticosteroids like prednisone are effective, their side effects outweigh the benefits in mild cases. Corticosteroids are typically reserved for cases with more severe thrombocytopenia or significant bleeding risk. Intravenous anti-D administration (Option B) is an intervention reserved for Rh-positive patients with more severe ITP requiring rapid platelet count elevation. In mild cases with minimal symptoms, this aggressive approach is unnecessary and carries potential risks. A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin (Option C) represents an aggressive and costly intervention that is not warranted in mild ITP cases. IVIG is typically reserved for severe cases with significant bleeding risk or very low platelet counts (<5,000/ µ L). Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Pages 371-373

questions.question: MC malignancy in children is:
questions.explanation: involves the abnormal production of white blood cells, which can interfere with the normal functioning of red blood cells and platelets. The two main types of leukemia in children are acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Symptoms can include fatigue, pale skin, frequent infections, easy bruising or bleeding, bone pain, swollen lymph nodes, and weight loss. Treatment for leukemia typically involves chemotherapy, sometimes combined with radiation therapy and stem cell transplantation. Incorrect options Option A) Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a rare form of eye cancer that primarily affects young children. It develops in the retina, the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye. Retinoblastoma may be hereditary or sporadic (non-hereditary). The most common sign is the presence of a white pupil or a noticeable difference in the color of the pupil between the two eyes. Other symptoms may include strabismus (crossed or misaligned eyes), poor vision, and eye pain. Treatment options include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, cryotherapy (freezing the tumor), and surgical removal of the affected eye. Option C) Wilms tumor: Wilms tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children. It usually occurs in children aged 3 to 4 years. The most common sign is the presence of a painless abdominal mass or swelling. Other symptoms may include abdominal pain, fever, and blood in the urine. Treatment involves surgical removal of the tumor, followed by chemotherapy and sometimes radiation therapy. The prognosis for Wilms tumor is generally favorable, with high survival rates. Option D ) Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is a cancer that develops from immature nerve cells, primarily affecting children aged 5 years or younger. It usually arises in the adrenal glands (located on top of the kidneys) or in nerve tissue along the spine, chest, abdomen, or pelvis. Neuroblastoma may cause various symptoms depending on the location and extent of the tumor, such as abdominal pain, a palpable mass, bone pain, fever, weight loss, and changes in bowel or bladder function. Treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. The prognosis for neuroblastoma can vary widely depending on factors such as the age at diagnosis, stage of the disease, and genetic characteristics. Reference: .
