questions.question: A 2-year-old child is experiencing symptoms that indicate anemia, but they are not specific. The examination of a sample of blood under a microscope reveals the presence of target cells. The child also has a low level of hemoglobin (6 gm%) and exhibits a picture of microcytic hypochromic. Additionally, there is a positive family history of this condition. The next step in the diagnostic process is to conduct which investigation?

options.A: Newborn screening for sickle cell disease

questions.explanation: quantify the different types of hemoglobin in the blood. It is particularly useful in diagnosing various types of hemoglobinopathies, including thalassemias and sickle cell disease. In the case of a 2-year-old child presenting with microcytic hypochromic anemia, a positive family history, and target cells on the peripheral smear, Hb electrophoresis is a crucial investigation to assess for the presence of any abnormal hemoglobin variants or thalassemias. Incorrect Options: Option A - Newborn screening for sickle cell disease: It is a test used to screen newborns for sickle cell disease. It is not typically used as a diagnostic test for anemia in a 2-year-old child presenting with nonspecific symptoms. Option B - HbA1c estimation: HbA1c is a blood test used primarily for the diagnosis and management of diabetes. Option D - Osmotic fragility test: The osmotic fragility test is a laboratory test that measures the susceptibility of red blood cells to burst when exposed to changes in osmotic pressure. It is primarily used to diagnose and monitor certain types of hereditary red blood cell disorders, such as hereditary spherocytosis. While it can be useful in specific cases of hemolytic anemias, it is not the most appropriate next investigation in this case, as the clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings suggest a microcytic hypochromic anemia.

questions.question: Which of the following parameters in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) indicates an unfavorable prognosis?
questions.explanation: and poorer outcomes. Incorrect Options: Option B: Leukocyte count < 50,000/mm3: A lower leukocyte count is associated with a more favorable prognosis in ALL. High leukocyte counts at diagnosis indicate a higher tumor burden and are considered a poor prognostic factor. Option C: Hyperdiploidy: Hyperdiploidy, which refers to the presence of more than the normal number of chromosomes in leukemic cells, is associated with a favorable prognosis in pediatric ALL. Option D: Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 10, and 17: Trisomies involving chromosomes 4, 10, and 17 are often observed in pediatric ALL and are associated with a more favorable prognosis. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the viral infection that can lead to temporary aplastic anemia?
questions.explanation: which is a temporary suppression of red blood cell production in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders, such as sickle cell disease or hereditary spherocytosis. Parvovirus B-19 infects erythroid precursor cells in the bone marrow, leading to their destruction and subsequent reduction in red blood cell production. Incorrect Options - A, B, and D do not cause temporary aplastic anemia.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Biliary atresia Explanation: Biliary atresia is not a characteristic feature of cystic fibrosis. While cystic fibrosis can cause liver damage and biliary cirrhosis due to obstructed bile ducts, biliary atresia is a separate congenital condition where there is a complete absence or abnormality of the bile ducts, leading to severe liver damage and jaundice. Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7q31.2 ( m/c mutation is ∆ F508), leading to a defective CFTR protein. Pathophysiology of Cystic Fibrosis: CFTR Protein Dysfunction Defective chloride transport across epithelial cells Increased sodium absorption Decreased water movement leading to dehydrated mucous surfaces Respiratory System Thick, viscous mucus leads to airway obstruction and bacterial colonization Chronic infection and inflammation Bronchiectasis, atelectasis, and respiratory failure Gastrointestinal System Thick secretions block pancreatic ducts leading to enzyme insufficiency Malabsorption of fats and proteins Meconium ileus in neonates Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome (DIOS) Hepatobiliary System Bile duct obstruction leading to biliary cirrhosis Sweat Glands Impaired chloride reabsorption leading to salty sweat Reproductive System Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility. Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility. Clinical Features of Cystic Fibrosis System Clinical Features Respiratory Chronic productive cough Recurrent respiratory infections Nasal polyps (Option A ruled out) Bronchiectasis Gastrointestinal Greasy stools (steatorrhea) Failure to thrive Rectal prolapse Malabsorption Meconium ileus in newborns (Option C ruled out) Genitourinary Infertility in males (due to congenital absence of vas deferens), delayed puberty Others Digital clubbing, Bleeding diathesis (Option D ruled out) , salt loss syndromes (hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis)

questions.question: During infancy, what is the most prevalent causative agent of acute bronchiolitis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D- Respiratory syncytial virus Explanation: The most common etiological agent responsible for acute bronchiolitis in infants is Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV). Bronchiolitis Age Group Infants between 1 and 6 months, but can affect children up to 2 years old. Seasonality Occurs primarily in winter and spring. Causative Agent Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) (Most common) Others include: Parainfluenza virus (Option B) Adenovirus Influenza virus (Option A) Rarely Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Risk factors M/c in male infants. Infants exposed to tobacco smoke, not breastfed, or living in crowded conditions. Maternal smoking Older family members/siblings (common source of infection) Protection IgG3 antibodies (short half-life, limited placental transfer) Breastfeeding provides IgA antibodies. Pathophysiology Bronchiolar obstruction with edema, mucus and cellular debris. Increased airway resistance during both inspiration and exhalation. Leads to expiratory wheezing, air trapping, lung hyperinflation and possible atelectasis. Hypoxemia due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch. With severe obstructive disease hypercapnia develops. Clinical Manifestations First develop upper respiratory symptoms: Sneezing and clear rhinorrhea. Fever (±) Diminished appetite Persistent Cough Dyspnea Irritability Respiratory distress Cyanosis. Physical Examination Prolonged expiratory time Wheezing Increased work of breathing with nasal flaring and retractions Accessory muscles of respiration are working Auscultation: Fine crepitations and rhonchi Faint or inaudible breath sounds in severe disease Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Edition 21st Page 2217,2219 OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics Edition 10th Page 406

questions.question: What is the most suitable course of action for managing a one and a half year old child who was brought to the hospital presenting symptoms of breathlessness, fever, cough, and cold, and upon examination has a respiratory rate of 46 breaths per minute, chest retractions, but no danger signs were present?

options.B: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
options.C: Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
options.D: No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate pneumonia based on WHO IMCI guidelines . The child presents with fast breathing (>40/min for ages 1-5 years) and chest retractions without any general danger signs . According to standard guidelines, this classification of pneumonia requires oral antibiotic therapy (5-day course of oral amoxicillin) with careful monitoring at home , rather than hospitalization or intravenous antibiotics. Pneumonia Classification: WHO IMNCI Guidelines Signs Classify as Treatment Presence of any general danger sign Severe pneumonia or very severe disease Give 1 dose of inj ampicillin & gentamycin & refer urgently to hospital Presence of either chest indrawing &/or fast breathing but no general danger sign Pneumonia Start oral Amoxicillin x 5 days. The child is sent home and assessed after 48 hours. If the child has improved, continue the same treatment. If the child has worsened, refer to a higher center. No fast breathing, no chest indrawing, no general danger signs No pneumonia: cough or cold only Home-based supportive care Fast Breathing Criteria: < 2 months: > 60/min 2-12 months: > 50/min 1-5 years: > 40/min General Danger signs: Convulsions Lethargy Inability to drink or breastfeed Persistent vomiting Unconsciousness Stridor in a calm child Incorrect Options: Give IV antibiotics and observe (Option A): IV antibiotics are reserved for severe pneumonia or cases with danger signs. This level of intervention is not warranted for a case without danger signs and represents overtreatment. Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre (Option B): Referral to a higher center is indicated only for severe cases with danger signs such as lethargy, inability to drink, or persistent vomiting. The child's current presentation does not warrant this level of care. No need of treatment only home remedies (Option D): This approach would be appropriate for cases with no fast breathing and no chest retractions. Given the presence of tachypnea and retractions, antibiotics are necessary, making home remedies alone insufficient. Reference: WHO Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) Guidelines, 2019 Edition, Pages 45-47 OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 402-405.

questions.question: Which of the following should be administered in addition to airway management for a 3-year-old child experiencing symptoms such as rapid breathing, high fever, noisy breathing during inhalation, and difficulty swallowing with excessive saliva production within 4-6 hours of the onset of fever?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) IV ceftriaxone Explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute epiglottitis. The primary treatment for acute epiglottitis is the prompt administration of intravenous antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime. Acute Epiglottitis Life-threatening infection that causes profound swelling of the upper airways, which can lead to asphyxia and respiratory arrest. Causative Agent Past Era (Pre-vaccine): Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) Post-vaccine Era: Streptococcus pneumoniae (M/c), Streptococcus pyogenes, non-typeable H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus Hib cases have decreased by 99% due to widespread vaccination. Clinical Features Child appears toxic with high fever , rapid breathing. Difficulty swallowing with excessive saliva production (drooling) . Neck hyperextension to maintain airway, Tripod position (sitting upright, leaning forward) Stridor (noisy breathing during inhalation) is a late sign indicating near-complete airway obstruction. Cyanosis, Coma. Diagnosis Laryngoscopy: Large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis Lateral neck X-ray: Thumb sign Treatment Immediate Treatment: Secure airway. Intubation decreases mortality from 6% to <1% in epiglottitis cases. Culture Collection: Blood, epiglottic surface and CSF in certain cases after the airway is stabilized. Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone , cefepime or meropenem given parenterally for 10 days. Recovery Symptoms improve with a few days of antibiotics, and the patient may be extubated.

questions.question: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities and irregular respiration. The heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is a grimace and some flexion. What is the APGAR score for this baby?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 5 Explanation: In the given case: Appearance: Pink body with blue extremities (score = 1) Pulse rate: 80 beats/min (score = 1) Grimace: Shows grimace (score = 1) Activity: Some flexion (score = 1) Respiratory effort: Irregular breathing (score = 1) Therefore, the total score is 5. APGAR score: The APGAR score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn’s condition. It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth. Resuscitation must be initiated before the 1 minute score is assigned. Therefore, it is not used to guide the resuscitation. 0 1 2 Appearance Completely blue or pale The body is pink, and the extremities are blue Completely pink Pulse rate Absent <100/min >100/min Grimace No response Grimaces only Coughs/sneezes Activity Limp and flaccid Some flexion present Flexed posture and actively moving limbs Respiratory effort None Slow and irregular Normal/strong Interpretation: Normal APGAR score is ≥ 7 Maximum score = 10; Minimum score = 0 Score for severe birth asphyxia = 0 - 3 Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th edition, Page 127 Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page 872

questions.question: Which of the following PFT findings in a child do not suggest asthma?

options.A: Increase in FEV1 > 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Day-night variation of FEV1 >15% Explanation: In asthma, lung function typically shows significant variability during the day, but the day-night variation of FEV1 is usually <15%. A variation >15% may indicate other conditions such as sleep apnea, or vocal cord dysfunction. Investigations of Asthma: Spirometry: Airflow limitation: Low FEV1 (relative to the percentage of predicted norms) FEV1/FVC ratio <0.80 (Option B) Bronchodilator response (to inhaled ß-agonist) assesses reversibility Reversibility is determined by an increase in either FEV1 >12% or Predicted FEV1 >12% after inhalation of a short-acting ß-agonist (SABA) (Option A) Exercise challenge: Worsening in FEV1 ≥ 15% (Option D) Daily peak expiratory flow (PEF) or FEV1 monitoring: Day-to-day and/or AM-to-PM variation ≥ 20% Exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO): A value of >20 ppb supports the clinical diagnosis of asthma in children FeNO can be used to predict response to ICS therapy Chest Radiographs: Chest radiographs often appear normal. May show subtle signs such as hyperinflation (flattening of the diaphragms) and peribronchial thickening Allergy Testing: Assesses sensitization to inhalant allergens. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page 1190,1191,1192 Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th edition, Page 408

questions.question: A 5-year-old male with a known history of asthma developed sudden onset breathlessness and wheezing. He was rushed to the emergency, where the preliminary assessment was done. The pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and the FEV1 is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is the best next step in treatment in this case?

options.A: A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization
options.B: High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer only
options.C: Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety
options.D: Nebulized anticholinergics to be added immediately as the mainstay of treatment

questions.explanation: nebulization Correct Answer A - A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization The FEV1 of 40%, tachypnea and tachycardia suggest that the acute exacerbation of asthma here is of the severe type that should be managed by providing oxygen therapy and salbutamol nebulization. Life-Threatening Asthma Management Overview Most severe asthma exacerbations require immediate attention. Indicators: Cyanosis, silent chest, poor respiratory effort, exhaustion, altered mental state, PEF <30%, oxygen saturation <90%. Immediate Management Oxygen Therapy : Administer for hypoxemia. Systemic Bronchodilators : Terbutaline or adrenaline subcutaneously; inhaled bronchodilators ( salbutamol , ipratropium). Systemic Corticosteroids: IV hydrocortisone (5 mg/kg). ICU Transfer: For monitoring and advanced care. ICU Management Continuous Monitoring: Vital signs, oxygen saturation, PEF. If Improvement Noted: Continue inhaled bronchodilators (salbutamol/terbutaline) every 20-30 minutes. Maintain hydrocortisone at 2-3 mg/kg every 6-8 hours until the patient can take oral medication. If No Improvement or Deterioration: Consider slow intravenous infusion of magnesium sulfate (50 mg/kg). Alternatively, administer a loading dose of theophylline. If these measures fail, prepare for mechanical ventilation. Address Underlying Causes: Check for acidosis, pneumothorax, electrolyte imbalance, and infection. Options B, C, and D are insufficient methods for the treatment of severe acute exacerbation of asthma and are hence incorrect. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page: 1206-1209.

questions.question: The following image is of the most common cause of stridor in children. Identify it.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Laryngomalacia The given image is a laryngoscopic view showing floppy tissues above the vocal cords and the inward curving of the epiglottis ( omega sign ) which points to the most common cause of stridor in children, laryngomalacia . Laryngomalacia Definition M/c congenital laryngeal anomaly in children; characterized by floppy tissues above the vocal cords that collapse during inspiration, causing stridor. Accounts for 45% to 75% of stridor cases in infants. Onset Appear within the first 2 weeks of life and can worsen for up to six months, with gradual improvement often occurring thereafter. Factors deciding severity and clinical course Gastroesophageal reflux disease Laryngopharyngeal reflux disease Neurological conditions Investigations Diagnosis is made mainly by clinical symptoms. Outpatient flexible laryngoscopy is done to confirm the diagnosis but is not suitable for a baby as well as when dysphagia is suspected. Laryngoscopy sows the omega sign: The inward curling of the epiglottis to become omega-shaped. Airway films and chest radiographs are done when the work of breathing is moderate to severe. A contrast swallow study or Flexible endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES) is considered when dysphagia is suspected. Complete bronchoscopy is done for those with moderate to severe obstruction. Treatment Expectant observation for most infants as the spontaneous resolution of symptoms as the child grows is seen. Laryngoesophageal reflux and GERD are treated with proton pump

questions.question: A child presents with acute exacerbation of asthma. Which of the following would you do? Chest X-ray Oxygen administration Salbutamol nebulization three times in 60 minutes Administration of oral corticosteroids
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 2, 3, 4 Explanation: In acute asthma exacerbation, oxygen administration, salbutamol nebulization, and oral corticosteroids are essential to stabilize the patient, while a chest X-ray is not routinely needed unless alternative diagnoses or complications are suspected. Management of Acute Asthma attacks Immediate Treatment Oxygen Therapy (2): Administer via mask or nasal cannula to maintain SpO2 > 92%. Inhaled SABAs (3): Albuterol: 2.5 mg/3 mL nebulized every 20 mins for 3 doses; Levalbuterol: 1.25 mg/0.5 mL up to 3 doses every 20 mins. Systemic Corticosteroids (4): Prednisone: 1-2 mg/kg/day orally (max 60 mg/day); Methylprednisolone: 1-2 mg/kg IV, then oral dosing. Adjunctive Treatments Inhaled Anticholinergics, Ipratropium Bromide: 0.5 mg nebulized every 6-8 hours as needed. Intravenous Magnesium Sulfate: 25-75 mg/kg IV over 20 minutes (max 2 grams). Escalation of Care Continuous Nebulization: Albuterol: 10-15 mg/hour via nebulizer. Parenteral β -Agonists: Terbutaline: 2-10 µg/kg IV loading dose followed by 0.1-0.4 microgram/kg/min titrate in 0.1-0.2 µg/kg/min increments every 30 min Epinephrine: 0.01 mg/kg SC or IM, repeat every 15-30 min if needed. Monitoring & Management Close Monitoring: Continuous monitoring of vital signs, oxygen saturation, and clinical response. Assess improvement in symptoms, PEF, and lung function. Risk Assessment for Discharge: Criteria: Sustained improvement, PEF > 70% predicted, oxygen saturation > 92% on room air. Ensure home capability for medication administration. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 1204-1206

questions.question: A 3-year-old was diagnosed with croup. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Influenza virus Explanation: Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis , is an upper respiratory tract infection that causes barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness due to inflammation of the larynx and trachea. It is most commonly caused by the parainfluenza virus , followed by the influenza virus . Among the given options, the influenza virus is the most appropriate choice. Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup): Viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions Causative Agent Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases. Other Viruses: Influenza A and B, Adenovirus, Respiratory syncytial virus, Measles. Age Group Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years. Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life. Initial Symptoms These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms. questions.question: Chloride level in sweat is used in the diagnosis of which disease:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cystic fibrosis Explanation: Chloride level in sweat is used to diagnose c ystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7q32. Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis (CF): Presence of one or more phenotypic features (or) A history of Cystic Fibrosis in a sibling (or) A positive neonatal screening test - Dried blood is checked for immunoreactive trypsinogen. Plus Laboratory evidence for CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis transmembrane regulator) dysfunction: Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations (highly specific test) obtained at separate labs > 60 mEq/L (or) Identification of two Cystic Fibrosis mutations by DNA sequencing (or) An abnormal transepithelial nasal potential difference measurement Investigations: Sweat Chloride Test: The gold standard for CF diagnosis , especially in symptomatic patients. Pilocarpine iontophoresis is used to stimulate sweat production, and chloride concentration is measured. A chloride concentration of: ≥ 60 mmol/L confirms CF in children and adults. 30-59 mmol/L indicates intermediate results, requiring further evaluation. In CF- sweat chloride levels are increased, while chloride levels are decreased in pancreatic secretions. Genetic Testing: Genetic testing, particularly for the common F508del mutation , is conducted if CF is suspected. Expanded genetic panels may include hundreds of mutations but are often limited in efficacy for rare variants. Nasal Potential Difference (NPD): This test measures the bioelectric properties of the respiratory epithelium, reflecting CFTR function. In CF, defective chloride and sodium transport leads to abnormal potential differences. NPD testing is helpful when sweat chloride tests are inconclusive and can provide a more direct assessment of CFTR functionality. Other Tests: Fecal Elastase: Used to evaluate pancreatic exocrine function, which is impaired in CF. Chest Imaging: Although not diagnostic, imaging can assess lung disease severity, showing bronchiectasis and hyperinflation common in CF patients. Transepithelial Intestinal and Rectal Biopsies: These can be used to directly evaluate CFTR function, though they are generally reserved for research or challenging cases. Serum electrolytes - hyponatremic, hypokalemic, hypochloremic alkalosis are seen in CF (contraction alkalosis) Phenylketonuria (Option A) is caused by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase , leading to high levels of phenylalanine. It is diagnosed by measuring plasma phenylalanine concentration, not by sweat chloride testing. Gaucher’s disease (Option C) results from a deficiency of ß-glucosidase, and diagnosis is made by testing ß-glucosidase activity in fibroblasts or leukocytes, along with genetic testing, not by sweat chloride levels. Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D) is caused by mutations in type-1 collagen genes, and it is diagnosed through genetic testing or DNA sequencing, not through sweat chloride measurement. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page 2176-2179. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/5507809_Cystic_fibrosis_in_adults_Diagnostic_and_therapeutic_aspects https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/cystic-fibrosis

questions.question: A newborn presented with chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The pediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to a deficiency of:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lecithin Explanation: Respiratory distress syndrome in a neonate is likely due to a deficiency of Lecithin. Respiratory Distress Syndrome/Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD): It is a common respiratory condition in preterm infants (<34 weeks of gestation) caused by surfactant deficiency. Pathophysiology: Surfactant is primarily produced by type II alveolar cells and reduces surface tension, preventing alveolar collapse at the end of expiration. Surfactant is composed of phospholipids, proteins, and lipids. Phosphatidylcholine, also known as lecithin , is a significant phospholipid in mature surfactants. Its production begins around 20 weeks of gestation and peaks at 35 weeks, so infants born before 35 weeks are at higher risk for RDS due to insufficient surfactant. Without adequate surfactant, alveoli collapse during expiration, impairing gas exchange and causing tissue hypoxia. This results in increased pulmonary pressure, ischemic damage, and the formation of a hyaline membrane from protein transudation. Clinical Features: Respiratory distress within the first 6 hours of life is characterised by tachypnea, retractions, grunting, cyanosis, and decreased air entry. Typical X-ray findings in RDS include: Ground glass haziness of lungs: Represents diffuse alveolar atelectasis, commonly seen in RDS. Presence of air bronchogram: Air-filled bronchi are visible against the hazy, collapsed alveoli, a classic feature of RDS. Air bronchogram can be seen in parenchymal pathology of the lung, such as consolidation, pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Reticulogranular pattern: Another term for the ground-glass appearance, indicating the fine, granular pattern throughout the lungs characteristic of RDS. Management: Neonates with this condition require admission to the neonatal intensive care unit, IV fluids, and appropriate respiratory support. Further management details are depicted in the table below, Dipalmitoyl inositol (Option A) : While it serves as a precursor in secondary messenger systems and plays roles in cell signaling and membrane trafficking, it is not involved in surfactant production or the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome. Sphingomyelin (Option C) is the dominant sphingolipid in the plasma membrane. The lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio in amniotic fluid is a marker of fetal lung maturity, but sphingomyelin itself does not directly contribute to alveolar stability. Dipalmitoylphosphatidylethanolamine (Option D) : Found in cell membranes, it lacks the essential surface tension-reducing properties of dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (lecithin), which is crucial for preventing alveolar collapse and respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy was brought in with a history of chronic cough and foul-smelling stools. His sibling, who had similar complaints, died a few years back. Sweat chloride test and CFTR gene studies were done. CFTR gene codes for proteins involved in the transport of
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cl- Explanation: The clinical scenario described is highly suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF), a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) gene. This gene encodes a chloride channel that plays a crucial role in the transport of chloride ions (Cl-) across epithelial cell membranes, particularly in the sweat glands, respiratory airways, and pancreatic ducts. Cystic fibrosis Genetic Basis Gene: CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) Location: Chromosome 7q31.2 Common Mutation: ∆ F508 Inheritance: Autosomal recessive Pathophysiology CFTR Dysfunction: Defective chloride transport, increased sodium absorption, dehydrated mucus Metabolic: (Hypokalemia) Due to excessive loss of potassium through sweat and impaired renal potassium handling Respiratory: Airway obstruction, bacterial colonization, bronchiectasis, respiratory failure Gastrointestinal: Pancreatic duct obstruction, malabsorption, Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome Sweat Glands: Salty sweat Reproductive: Infertility in males: Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility. Infertility in females: Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility. Clinical Features Respiratory: Chronic productive cough, recurrent infections, bronchiectasis Gastrointestinal: Steatorrhea, malabsorption, meconium ileus, failure to thrive Genitourinary: Infertility (males), delayed puberty Other: Digital clubbing, salt-loss syndromes (Contraction alkalosis) Diagnosis Diagnostic Criteria Requirement 1: Any ONE of the following Clinical Features: Presence of typical features Family History: A sibling with diagnosed cystic fibrosis Newborn Screening: Positive result indicating risk for CF IRT Screening: Elevated Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT) for pancreatic insufficiency Requirement 2: At least ONE of the following Laboratory Evidence: Sweat Chloride Test: Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations on separate days ≥ 60 mMol/L (Pilocarpine iontophoresis method) CFTR Mutations: Identification of two CFTR mutations Nasal Potential Difference: Abnormal measurement Microbes <18 years: Staphylococcus aureus >18 years: Pseudomonas aeruginosa Burkholderia cepacia: High mortality, low incidence Management Strategies Airway Clearance: Chest physiotherapy, percussion, postural drainage Infection Control: Antibiotics, CFTR modulators Nutritional Support: High-calorie diet, Pancreatic Enzyme Replacement Therapy Vitamin supplementation (A, D, E, K) Other: Insulin for CFRD, bone health management Advanced Therapies CFTR Modulators: Ivacaftor, lumacaftor, Trikafta Trikafta: Elexacaftor-Tezacaftor-Ivacaftor ( ≥ 2 years old), improves lung function, reduces sweat chloride

questions.question: A 9-month-old child is brought to the PHC with a fever and cough. She is feeding well and has normal urine output. On examination, a respiratory rate of 48 breaths/min is found, and no chest indrawing is seen. What is the next step of management?

options.A: Explain danger signs and send home
options.B: No pneumonia—Give amoxyclav + paracetamol and send home
options.D: Refer as the child has severe pneumonia

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Explain danger signs and send home Explanation: The clinical scenario involves a 9-month-old child with fever and cough but without severe symptoms like chest indrawing, which would indicate severe pneumonia. The child's respiratory rate (RR) is 48 breaths per minute, which is normal for this age (RR >60/min would be abnormal for infants). According to the IMNCI guidelines, pneumonia is suspected if: RR >60 breaths/min for infants <2 months RR >50 breaths/min for infants 2-12 months RR >40 breaths/min for children 12 months to 6 years Lower chest wall indrawing, a sign of moderate pneumonia, is absent here. Severe pneumonia involves danger signs like lethargy, inability to drink, persistent vomiting, and convulsions, which are not present in this case. Based on this assessment, the child does not have severe pneumonia. The next step is to explain the danger signs to the caregiver and send the child home with appropriate follow-up instructions. Pneumonia Etiology Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV): Leading viral cause of pneumonia in infants. Streptococcus pneumoniae: M/c bacterial cause in children, particularly aged 1-3 months. Pneumocystis jirovecii: Common in HIV-infected infants, especially where ART and PCP prophylaxis are limited. Other Bacteria: E. coli, Gram-negative bacilli, Haemophilus influenzae, Group B streptococcus. Other Viruses: Rhinoviruses, parainfluenza, influenza, human metapneumovirus, adenovirus. Other Fungal: Histoplasma, Aspergillus, Blastomyces, Cryptococcus, mucormycosis, Coccidioides. Parasitic: Ascaris, Strongyloides. Mycobacterium: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium avium complex. Assessment and Classification of the Sick Child (Age 2 Months Up to 5 Years) Initial Assessment: A thorough history from the mother is essential Check for General Danger Signs: Ask Look Action Able to drink or breastfeed? Does the child vomit everything? H/O convulsions during this illness? Lethargic or unconscious? Currently convulsing? If any danger signs are present, the child needs URGENT attention. Assess Cough or Difficulty Breathing Ask: How long has the child had a cough or difficulty breathing? Look, Listen, Feel: Count the breaths per minute (use respiratory rate timers if available). Fast Breathing Criteria: Age 2 months up to 12 months: ≥ 50 breaths per minute. Age 12 months up to 5 years: ≥ 40 breaths per minute. Look for: Chest in-drawing. Stridor, wheeze. Central cyanosis. Oxygen saturation. Use the AVPU scale (Alert, Voice, Pain, Unresponsive). Assess for possible asthma/TB if the child has wheezing with chest in-drawing or fast breathing. Classification of Pneumonia and Management Classification Signs Treatment Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease Any general danger sign Oxygen saturation < 90% Stridor in calm child Central cyanosis Convulsions AVPU = V, P, or U Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%. Administer Benzyl Penicillin (or Ampicillin) & Gentamicin. Ceftriaxone should be used as a second-line treatment in children with severe pneumonia having failed on the first-line treatment. Give diazepam if convulsing. Prevent hypoglycemia. Treat wheeze if present. Urgent referral or admission. Pneumonia Chest indrawing in calm child

questions.question: A neonate was born to a controlled gestational diabetes mother. At the time of birth, he was fine but 4 days later, he developed dyspnea with Spo2 80% at room air. What is the initial management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Give 100% O2 Explanation: In this scenario, the child developed the symptoms after 4 days of birth, and the aetiology can be cardiac (cyanotic heart disease) or pulmonary. Hence, the best method is to give 100% oxygen to the neonate to distinguish the cause. If the saturation improves, the cause is respiratory, and if not, the cause is cardiogenic. This is called the hyperoxia test. Hyperoxia test for distinguishing CCHD from pulmonary disease This is the initial method to differentiate congenital critical heart disease (CCHD) from pulmonary disease. Procedure: Measure arterial blood gases (ABG) first at room air and then again after administering 100% oxygen for 10 minutes. Expected results in CCHD: Neonates with CCHD usually fail to increase PaO2 above 100 mm Hg with 100% oxygen. Expected Results in Pulmonary Disease: In pulmonary disease, PaO2 typically increases to ≥ 100 mm Hg when given 100% oxygen, as ventilation-perfusion mismatch is corrected. Interpretation: A positive result (failure to increase PaO2) suggests a cardiac origin, warranting further cardiac evaluation to rule out CCHD. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK500001/

In this case, the child's symptoms do not suggest the need for immediate referral to a higher center. Option D: Administer only home remedies: Home remedies alone are not sufficient for managing respiratory tract infections, especially if there is a suspicion of a bacterial infection. While supportive care measures like maintaining hydration and providing symptomatic relief can be recommended, appropriate antibiotic therapy is often required to treat bacterial infections.

questions.question: In a child presenting with a beaded appearance in the chest with the following X-ray, what is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Rickets Explanation: The radiograph showing metaphyseal fraying and cupping and the clinical presentation of a beaded appearance on the chest (rachitic rosary) are characteristic features of rickets caused due to vitamin D deficiency. questions.question: A 15-year-old boy presents with short stature. On examination, his US/LS ratio is 0.8:1. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: inheritable dysplasia of the bone due to a defect in collagen. It can present a significant reduction in the upper segment to a lower segment ratio- short trunk dwarfism. The patient's decreased upper segment to lower segment (US/LS) ratio of 0.8:1 points towards the diagnosis of spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia. Incorrect Options Option B – Achondroplasia: Achondroplasia results in short-limb dwarfism, so US/LS is likely to be increased. Option C - Growth hormone deficiency: Growth hormone deficiency results in proportionate short stature with a normal US/LS ratio. Option D – Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism also results in short-limb dwarfism, so US/LS is likely to be increased. Reference: .

questions.question: Dystrophin protein is absent completely in which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene characterised by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness. DMD progresses rapidly and leads to loss of ambulation in the early teenage years. It is associated with cognitive impairment and a high incidence of cardiomyopathy and respiratory complications , which typically determine life expectancy. Aspect Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) (Option A) Type of Mutation Frameshift mutations lead to a disrupted reading frame In-frame mutations that preserve the reading frame Dystrophin Protein Dystrophin deficient Truncated and unstable (< 3% of normal) Abnormal dystrophin Partially functional (20–90% of normal) Clinical Severity Severe, early onset, rapid progression Milder, later onset, slower progression Inheritance Pattern X-linked recessive X-linked recessive Age of onset Early childhood (Before 5 years) Later childhood (After 5-7 years) Myasthenia gravis (MG) (Option C) is a chronic autoimmune disease of the neuromuscular junction (postsynaptic end plate) that leads to abnormal neuromuscular transmission or blockade. Blockade of presynaptic calcium channels at the neuromuscular junction is characteristic of Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) (Option D) . In LEMS, autoantibodies target voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs) on presynaptic nerve terminals. This leads to a reduction in acetylcholine (ACh) release, which causes muscle weakness. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page: 3283.

questions.question: A 6-year-old girl, born out of a non-consanguineous marriage, presented with rachitic changes in her limbs since the age of 2 despite receiving several rounds of vitamin D treatment. Investigations are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? Parameter Lab determined value Serum Calcium 9.5 mg/dL Serum Phosphate 1.6 mg/dL ALP 814 IU PTH Within normal limits Serum electrolytes Within normal limits Serum creatinine Within normal limits ABG Within normal limits
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Hypophosphatemic rickets The patient’s presentation with rachitic changes in limbs since the age of 2 and receiving multiple courses of vitamin D with a normal calcium level and a low phosphate level is suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets. Hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder characterized by impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate, resulting in low levels of serum phosphate (hypophosphatemia). This leads to defective bone mineralization, resulting in rachitic changes in the bones. Disorder Calcium PTH ALP 25-(OH)D 1,25-(OH)D Urine Calcium Vitamin D deficiency N, I I I I I I ,N, I I Vitamin D dependent rickets Type 1 N, I I I I N, I N, I I Vitamin D dependent ricketsType 2 N, I I I I N II I Chronic kidney disease N, I I I I N I N, I X- linked hypophosphatemic rickets N I N, I I N I I Autosomal dominant hypophosphatemic rickets N I N I N I I Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria N I N, I I N I I Autosomal recessive hypophosphatemic rickets N I N I N I I Dietary calcium deficiency N, I I I I N I I Vitamin D dependent rickets (Option A) can occur due to impaired vitamin D metabolism or receptor defects. However, in this case, the PTH is normal, which is not consistent with vitamin D-dependent rickets, where PTH levels are typically high. Hypoparathyroidism (Option B) is characterized by low levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) leading to low calcium levels and high phosphate levels. However, in the given scenario, the PTH level is within normal limits, ruling out hypoparathyroidism. Chronic renal failure (Option C) can cause renal tubular dysfunction, leading to electrolyte imbalances and bone abnormalities. However, in the given scenario, the serum electrolytes and creatinine levels are within normal limits, indicating normal renal function. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page 376, 377, 378, 381, 382

questions.question: What is the diagnosis for a 4-year-old boy who has muscle weakness, difficulty climbing stairs, and getting up from the floor, with a muscle biopsy showing small muscle fibrils and absence of dystrophin?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Duchenne muscular dystrophy Explanation: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness. It is caused by mutations in the DMD gene that encodes the protein dystrophin. Symptoms: Children with DMD typically show signs of muscle weakness, difficulty climbing stairs, and getting up from the floor . Diagnosis: The clinical presentation, along with the muscle biopsy showing absence of dystrophin, confirms the diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) vs Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) : Aspect Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) Type of Mutation Frameshift mutations leading to a disrupted reading frame In frame mutations that preserve the reading frame Dystrophin Protein Dystrophin deficient Truncated and unstable (< 3% of normal) Abnormal dystrophin Partially functional (20–90% of normal) Inheritance Pattern X-linked recessive Age of onset Early childhood (Before 5 years) Later childhood (After 5-7 years) Clinical Severity Severe, early onset, rapid progression Milder, later onset, slower progression Nonambulatory by 9-10.5 years of age > 15 years of age Additional Symptoms Early onset of myalgia, rhabdomyolysis, and respiratory distress None or milder Becker Muscular Dystrophy (Option A) is also caused by mutations in the DMD gene but typically results in partially functional dystrophin. Symptoms are similar to DMD but milder and with later onset. Muscle biopsy would show reduced but not absent dystrophin. Myotonic dystrophy (Option C) is a different genetic disorder caused by mutations in the DMPK or CNBP genes. It involves myotonia (difficulty relaxing muscles), cataracts, and cardiac abnormalities and muscle biopsy would not show absence of dystrophin. Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMD) (Option D) involves a group of disorders affecting the voluntary muscles, particularly around the hips and shoulders. It typically shows a different pattern of muscle involvement and genetic mutations, and muscle biopsy would not show the absence of dystrophin but might show other abnormalities. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page 3283 Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th edition, Page 614

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets?

options.C: It is the most common cause of rickets

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) PHEX gene is affected Explanation: X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (XLH) is characterized by mutations in the PHEX gene. This gene encodes the phosphate-regulating endopeptidase homolog X-linked (PHEX) protein , which plays a crucial role in phosphate homeostasis. When the PHEX gene is mutated, it leads to increased FGF-23 levels , resulting in impaired phosphate reabsorption in the renal tubules and subsequent hypophosphatemia. XLH is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern and presents with characteristic features including lower limb deformities, dental abnormalities, and skeletal manifestations without typical hypocalcemic symptoms. X-Linked Hypophosphatemic (XLH) Rickets Prevalence 1 in 20,000. Most common among genetic disorders causing rickets Inheritance X-linked dominant Gene Mutated PHEX (phosphate-regulating gene with homology to endopeptidases on X chromosome) Normally, product of this gene appears to have an indirect role in inactivating FGF-23 Pathophysiology Clinical Manifestations Lower limb deformities: Coxa vara Genu valgum Genu varum Poor growth Maxillofacial abnormalities Skull deformities: Due to premature fusion of cranial sutures Delayed dentition Short stature Laboratory Findings High renal phosphate excretion Hypophosphatemia Elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) Normal PTH and serum calcium Low or inappropriately normal levels of 1,25-D Treatment Phosphorus Supplementation: 1-3 g elemental phosphorus daily, divided into 4-5 doses Can be given in the form of Joulie solution (30.4 mg phosphate/mL) or as neutral phosphate effervescent tablets Frequent dosing helps to prevent prolonged decrements in serum phosphorus because there is rapid decline after each dose Calcitriol: 30-70 ng/kg/day in 2 doses Burosumab-twza: Monoclonal antibody targeting FGF-23, an alternative for children >1 year Prognosis Generally good response to therapy, though frequent dosing can affect compliance FGF-23 levels decreased (Option A) : This is incorrect because XLH is characterized by elevated levels of FGF-23, not decreased levels. The increased FGF-23 leads to phosphate wasting and decreased active vitamin D production, which are hallmark features of the condition. It is the most common cause of rickets (Option C) : This statement is incorrect because while XLH is the most common inherited form of rickets, nutritional deficiencies, particularly vitamin D deficiency, remain the most common overall cause of rickets worldwide. Excretion of phosphorus is decreased (Option D) : This statement contradicts the pathophysiology of XLH, where there is increased renal phosphate wasting leading to elevated urinary phosphorus excretion. This increased phosphate excretion is a direct result of elevated FGF-23 levels and is a key diagnostic feature of the condition.

questions.question: The X-ray image of a child with muscle weakness and failure to thrive is attached below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Rickets Explanation: The radiographical features such as widened or irregular growth plates in the phalanges and metacarpals & metaphyses near the growth plates showing a cupped or flared appearance indicate the diagnosis of Rickets. Rickets is a condition that primarily affects growing children and is caused by a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. Radiological Changes: Decreased Calcification: Leads to the thickening of the growth plate. Fraying: Initial change is the loss of the normal zone of provisional calcification adjacent to the metaphysis, which appears as a blurring or frayed appearance of the metaphyseal margin. Cupping: Edge of the metaphysis changes from a convex or flat surface to a more concave surface, particularly noticeable at the distal ends of the radius, ulna, and fibula. Splaying: Cartilage hypertrophy leads to the widening of the growth plate resulting in the widening (splaying) of the metaphyseal ends. Generalized reduction in bone density: Osteopenia Widening of the Metaphysis Scurvy (Option A): Shows different radiological features, including ground-glass appearance and Wimberger's ring sign. Osteomalacia (Option C): Similar to rickets but occurs in adults and radiographically suggests growth plate closure. Osteopetrosis (Option D): Shows increased bone density rather than the decreased density seen here.

questions.question: A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated fractures for the past 2 years. On examination, blue sclera and dental abnormalities are noted. There is a family history of similar complaints. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Osteogenesis imperfecta Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) based on the classic triad of repeated fractures, blue sclera, and dental abnormalities , along with a positive family history. Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI): It is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for producing type I collagen , which is the primary component of the bone matrix. This defective collagen synthesis leads to brittle bones, resulting in frequent fractures from minimal trauma. Additional clinical features like blue sclerae, hearing loss, and joint hypermobility are also seen in OI. Features of Osteogenesis Imperfecta: Pathophysiology Defective type I collagen synthesis Genetic Mutations Type I-IV: COL1A1, COL1A2 Type V: IFITM5 Type VI: SERPINF1 Key Clinical Features Recurrent fractures from minimal trauma, blue sclerae, hearing loss, joint hypermobility, osteopenia Complications Cardiopulmonary issues (pneumonia, cor pulmonale), neurological complications (basilar invagination, brainstem compression) Differential Diagnosis Rickets, osteopetrosis, and disorders related to abnormal calcium metabolism Treatment Physical rehabilitation, Bisphosphonates, growth hormone, orthopedic management (fracture care, surgery) Scurvy (Option A) is a vitamin C deficiency disorder characterized by weakness, fatigue, joint pain, easy bruising, and poor wound healing. While it can cause bone abnormalities, it does not present with blue sclera or repeated fractures. Rickets (Option B) results in impaired bone mineralization and skeletal deformities due to vitamin D deficiency or metabolism disorders, but does not present with blue sclera and dental abnormalities. Osteomalacia (Option D) is characterized by softening of bones due to impaired mineralization caused by vitamin D deficiency in adults. However it does not present with repeated fractures in children. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Edition 21, Page no: 3736, 3737

questions.question: A pediatric patient arrives at the hospital complaining of several abnormal fractures, and the X-ray shows the image shown below. The blood tests indicate low levels of phosphorus and calcium, normal levels of Vitamin D, and increased levels of PTH. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: phosphorus and calcium levels, normal Vitamin D levels, and elevated PTH along with the X-ray findings is suggestive of osteopetrosis. Osteopetrosis is a genetic disorder characterized by defective osteoclast function, leading to increased bone density and susceptibility to fractures. Incorrect Options: Option B - Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia is characterized by softening of the bones due to vitamin D deficiency or impaired metabolism. However, in this case, the vitamin D levels are normal. Option C - Osteosclerosis: Osteosclerosis refers to abnormal hardening or increased density of the bones, but it does not present with multiple pathological fractures. Option D - Histiocytosis X: Histiocytosis X (also known as Langerhans cell histiocytosis) is a group of disorders characterized by abnormal proliferation of certain immune cells called Langerhans cells. It does not present with findings described in the question. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a 7-year-old child who complains of leg pain and had a fever and cough three days ago? The calf muscles are tender on palpation, but reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Laboratory testing shows CK levels of 2000 IU.
questions.explanation: cough three days ago with tenderness in calf muscles on palpation and increased creatine kinase is suggestive of viral myositis. Viral myositis presents with muscle pain, tenderness, and sometimes swelling. The elevation of creatine kinase (CK) levels in the blood is an indication of muscle damage or breakdown. Incorrect Options: Option B - Duchenne muscular dystrophy: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting. It usually manifests in early childhood and is not typically associated with a recent history of fever and cough. Option C - GBS: GBS is an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system. It causes muscle weakness and can lead to paralysis. It is unlikely in this case as there are no signs of neurological involvement or abnormal reflexes. Option D - Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory muscle disease that primarily affects the skin and muscles. It usually presents with characteristic skin rash along with muscle weakness. The absence of skin rash in this case makes dermatomyositis less likely.

questions.question: Which of the following malignant tumors, commonly found in children, has a high tendency to spread to the bone marrow?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Neuroblastoma Explanation: Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumor arising from neural crest cells and is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood. It frequently presents with widespread metastatic disease at diagnosis, with bone marrow being one of the most common sites of metastasis . This characteristic bone marrow involvement often leads to pancytopenia and is a factor used for disease staging and prognosis. Neuroblastoma Definition & Epidemiology Neural crest-derived tumor Most common extracranial solid tumor in children 7-8% of all childhood cancers Most common in first year of life Median age at diagnosis: 19 months Genetic Features MYCN amplification (~20% of cases) Loss of heterozygosity: 1p, 11q, 14q, 17q TERT and chromatin remodeling genes 1-2% show family history Higher MYCN copy number indicates worse prognosis Clinical Presentation Primary Sites: Abdominal (65%) Mediastinal (40%) Paraspinal (19%) Head/neck (5%) Symptoms: Pain, fever, irritability Weight loss Abdominal distension Periorbital ecchymosis Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (rare) International Staging Stage L1: Localized tumor, complete excision Stage IIA: Incomplete gross excision Stage IIB: Complete/incomplete excision with positive lymph nodes Stage III: Midline crossing or bilateral involvement Stage IV: Distant metastasis (Bone marrow (MC), bone, liver, regional lymph nodes) Stage IVS : Localized primary with limited dissemination (infants) Diagnostic Markers Immunohistochemistry: Synaptophysin Tyrosine hydroxylase PHOX2B Neuron-specific enolase Other Markers: Desmin Myogenin Keratin CD99 Treatment Options Primary Treatments: Surgery Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Regimens: OPEC (vincristine, cyclophosphamide, cisplatin) CADO (vincristine, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin) PECADO (cisplatin, etoposide) Additional Therapies: 13-cis retinoic acid Autologous bone marrow transplantation Wilms tumor (Option A) primarily metastasizes to the lungs, liver, and regional lymph nodes. While it is the most common renal tumor in children, bone marrow involvement is not a characteristic feature. The typical pattern of spread follows hematogenous routes to the lungs and liver. Adrenal gland tumors (Option C), such as adrenocortical carcinomas, typically spread to local lymph nodes, liver, and lungs. Bone marrow metastasis is not a common feature of these tumors. Granulosa cell tumor of ovary (Option D) typically spreads within the peritoneal cavity and to regional lymph nodes. It is rare in children, and bone marrow metastasis is not a characteristic feature. These tumors are more commonly seen in adults.
